title: CNN: Scientists in the US are flying planes into clouds to make it snow more
creator: Jennifer Gray and Rachel Ramirez, CNN
description:
With 61% of the contiguous US in drought, wouldn’t it be nice if we could just “make it rain” or just “make more snow?”
Well, certain parts of the country are doing just that, sort of. It’s called cloud seeding, and it’s nothing new.
It’s been around since the 1940s and countries all over the world have been doing it for various reasons (most notably China), but it’s a growing practice in the US, especially in the drought-stricken West.
subject: weather modification
source: Gray, J., & Ramirez, R. (2022, March 14). Scientists in the US are flying planes into clouds to make it snow more. CNN. https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/14/weather/cloud-seeding-weather-modification-wxn/index.html

title: The War against Trucks Aerial Interdiction in Southern Laos 1968-1972
creator: Bernard C. Nalty
description: An overview of the US Air Force's six years of weather modification activities using photoflash cartriges, stating the results were not convincing.
subject: military weather modification
source: Nalty, B. (2005). The War Against Trucks Aerial Interdication in Southern Laos 1968-1972. Air Force History and Museums Program.

title: Cover Page: The War against Trucks Aerial Interdiction in Southern Laos 1968-1972
creator: Bernard C. Nalty
description: Nalty examines the U.S. Air Force's efforts to disrupt the Ho Chi Minh Trail during the Vietnam War, a critical supply route for North Vietnamese forces. Besides the implementation of advanced warfare technologies like surveillance systems and air patrol, they also explored weather modification techniques. They employed cloud seeding to intensify rainfall in order to obstruct enemy transportation. However, terrain challenges and countermeasures limit the campaign's impact, leading to broader discussions on their effectiveness
subject: military weather modification
source: Nalty, B. (2005). The War Against Trucks Aerial Interdication in Southern Laos 1968-1972. Air Force History and Museums Program.

title: Senate Hearing, 93rd Congress - Weather modification: hearings before the Subcommittee on Oceans and International Environment of the Committee on Foreign Relations
creator: Subcommittee on Oceans and International Environment
description:
This early experiment in the 1890s tried to conduct weather modification by creating rain over portions of Texas between the towns of San Diego and El Paso. The Department of Agriculture was trying to see if explosions from balloons could cause rainfall due to concussive activity. While there were eyewitness accounts to attest to the creation of rainfall, there were other proven methods. Trying to induce rainfall via explosions from balloons was also a high cost. 
This 1892 letter presents the U.S. government's early attempt at weather modifications. Although the experiment proved that concussion force can trigger rain, it was deemed costly and impractical. Seeing such an early exploration and how it evolves despite its lack of definitive success is fascinating.
subject: congress weather modification
source: Fulbright, J. W. (1974). Weather Modications. Senate Subcommittee on Oceans and the Environment.

title: Previously Classified CIA Weather Modification Memo
creator: Chief, Astro-Geophysics Branch
description:
This internal CIA document lists many beneficial uses of weather modification if the US can realize accurate control of the weather. It also states that the CIA has a good working relationship with the National Science Foundation (NSF), which operates a US civilian weather modification program. The memo also highlights that the Soviet Union is also working on a weather modification program. Lastly, this memo notes the expected increase in United States funding within many Federal Agencies for this type of research.
This document solidifies that many US Federal Agencies were keen on finding beneficial uses for weather modification to aid their missions, from warfare to drought mitigation to limiting destructive hurricane forces. The funding came from many different Federal sources, so the research into weather modification needed to be more cohesive and coordinated. This memo shows the need for a unified approach to weather modification research, which was ultimately placed under NOAA (National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration).
subject: 1960s weather modification
source: Chief, Astro-Geophysics Branch, (1965).  Classified Memo. Chief, Central Intelligence Agency. https://www.cia.gov/readingroom/document/cia-rdp68r00530a000200110020-2

title: Annual Report to The President and The Congress by the National Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere
creator: National Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere
description: NACOA's inaugural annual report comprehensively analyzed oceanic and atmospheric policy challenges. The report established foundational guidelines for future environmental governance through a detailed examination of maritime law, fisheries rehabilitation strategies, weather modification initiatives, and coastal management frameworks. NACOA calls for more decisive federal leadership in these areas, recommending that NOAA take the lead in coordinating efforts related to weather modification and other atmospheric issues.
source: United States. National Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere. (1972). A report to the President and the Congress. Washington, D.C.: The Committee .

title: Project StormFury 1971 Annual Report
creator: Departments of Navy and Commerce
description:
The Project Stormfury Annual Report, 1971 outlines the progress and findings of a U.S. government initiative to modify hurricanes through cloud seeding. Conducted under the joint auspices of the U.S. Department of the Navy and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the report details experimental efforts to weaken tropical cyclones by dispersing silver iodide into their eyewalls. The document provides an overview of the scientific methods, results, and challenges faced during the 1971 season, reflecting on the feasibility of hurricane modification to reduce storm damage.
This source effectively highlights the scope and ambition of Project Stormfury, offering valuable insights into mid-20th-century meteorological experimentation and its intersection with government policy. However, its technical nature and focus on scientific details may make it less accessible to general readers or those unfamiliar with meteorological concepts. As an information source, it is highly specialized and most useful for researchers studying weather modification history or government-led scientific initiatives. Its utility could be enhanced with more straightforward explanations of technical terms and broader contextualization of its significance within climate science advancements
subject: Project Storm Fury
source: White, R. M. (1972), 1971 Project Storm Fury Annual Report, Department of Commerce and the Deparment of the Navy. Retrieved from the Digital Public Library of America, http://digitalcollections.lib.washington.edu/cdm/ref/collection/ww-text/id/13507

title: Letter from the Secretary of Agriculture, in response to Senate resolution of February 23, 1892, transmitting the report of the agent of the Department of Agriculture for making experiments in the production of rainfall
creator: Department of Agriculture
description:
his early experiment in the 1890s tried to conduct weather modification by creating rain over portions of Texas between the towns of San Diego and El Paso. The Department of Agriculture was trying to see if explosions from balloons could cause rainfall due to concussive activity. While there were eyewitness accounts to attest to the creation of rainfall, there were other proven methods. Trying to induce rainfall via explosions from balloons was also expensive.
Although the experiment proved that concussion force can trigger rain, it was deemed costly and impractical at the time. It is fascinating to see such an early exploration and how it evolved despite its lack of definitive success.
